article_title: Focus on research: Unilateral presidential power in an age of polarized politics
article_text:
Unilateral powers are policies that presidents design without Congress or the courts

The Constitution is silent on presidents legislating and acting on their own

Presidents have issued more than 15,000 executive orders

article_metadata.news-keywords: focus on research, penn state research, mark major, presidental power, executive orders
article_metadata.description: Presidential power, especially their unilateral authority, has been a fierce point of contention in the Obama era. Recently, 43 senators, all Republican, filed a friend-of-the-court brief challenging President Barack Obama’s, as they put it, “extra-constitutional assertion of a unilateral executive power” over immigration policy. The public, and many in the press, assume that the controversy centers on an executive order. This is incorrect.
